text: our next session is Nadia Mansour
she is a British Pakistani actor writer and producer who has a critically
acclaimed autobuyer autobuyer graphical one-woman show birkoff which has been
sold out in major cities all across the world New York LA San Francisco London
Toronto so she's a creator of sheds and fats a Gotham award-winning web series
that spy light spotlights the muslim-american experience through spotlight comedy through slapstick
comedy and was recently named one of the 25 new faces of independent film by
filmmaker magazine one of the reasons when we saw Nadia's work that we were so
excited to bring her to the conference and sort of speaks to some of the themes that we've been discussing all day from this morning it was really this sort of
how do you play with different identities especially identities that
sit at the intersection of nationality ethnicity culture gender and in
particular how do you play with them in ways that are that provide more insight
and meeting so a different way of knowing a different way of telling and a different way of learning and so we're
really excited to to have Nadia come here and maybe evoke some of these ideas about you know Laura started us off this
morning with you know I can't use the medium of intellectual sentences and
words that have to get published in a journal manuscript because the emotion needs expression in a different way and
you know Herminia showed us this beautiful sort of the video of the embodied experience of how all of these identities come
together and we saw that across many of the panels that suspension in midair skiing photographs that that Jean
Pierrot showed us and so really different ways of playing with identities that embody many different
ways of knowing and telling and learning so that really was our inspiration and I hope I hope you all enjoy Nadia's time
she's going to do a half an hour of just a show so her invitation is to please scooch as close as you can so it feels a bit more

and at about 510 we'll stop and move to our buses and reconvene again for dinner

much one of the things that I was sort of speaking about thank you so much is about the explicit binary understanding
of gender I was sort of educated by through my dad and very explicitly through the difference between my
brother and myself so very much with the focus of a woman being small silent
taking up a lot of room whereas my brother was sort of being you know trained for world domination having to
know all of the capitals of the world and I was essentially not meant to get fat and this is extremely explicit in my
home and so I sort of like broke it down into these two aspects of like my gender
training one in terms of the behavior in terms of who I was meant to be and the other which I bring out a lot in this
play is through dress and I speak a lot about the burqa and the bikini I
actually show two very similar portions of the play the first time that I wear
the burqa and the first time I wear the bikini and how they're actually equally liberating experiences for me one being
in Mecca one sort of feeling this freedom for the first time in my life because I feel the ability to be
invisible in the demonic male gaze that my dad has sort of set up as the world
around me and then equally when I wear a burka for the first time in secret it's
sort of equally liberating because I'm able to walk around you know in a tiny
string and not feel objectified because everybody doesn't care because everybody is you know okay with expressing
themselves in that way and one of the sort of insights that I took from this is how these were equally liberating
times for me but how often women's liberation is tied to their dress and is
tied to their image and is tied to the objectification right as opposed to what they're able to give and speak and
present and so that's sort of one thing I would love to explore with you and if you have any questions and then the
second thing that I'm really interested in and I'm continuing to sort of think about in my next show which is called
jerk off the sequel to birkoff we like rhymes and
it's very much about how the head job which I actually find problematic is
because it really does perpetuate the binary between men and women women having to carry the burden of shame that
they are inherently sexual there are something inherently different that needs to be covered up and protected I
obviously have a problem with and also in terms of managing sort of this
inherent understood male gaze right so one thing that I was taught throughout
my life is that men are dogs understand it and you should wear a hijab in order to manage the male gaze and so these are

meant to be in order to be accepted through my community and my family as a good Muslim woman and it had all of

day that I came from and it ended up being a play but what was really interesting to me is through the
performance of all of these contradictions of my past by playing all of these different characters that was
really when I was able to understand my authentic self when I was able to really
stand on my own two feet which was the ability to sort of internalized all of these contradictions but there is no one
way of being and that really helped that really happen through performing so I
really found a power in that and that sort of some of the things I wanted to share and and I'd love to just open it up I find
